Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: I had promised Mia this weekend would be just for us—her last before she left for London. We’d planned everything: a quiet dinner, a walk by the river, and hours just talking, holding on to every moment. But as I stood in the courtroom, robe heavy on my shoulders, I was deep into jury instructions when my clerk slipped me a note. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was explaining. My heart thudded. I knew I had to stop, review the new ruling, and rewrite my instructions—right now. The law demanded it. But my phone buzzed in my pocket: Mia’s message, “Can’t wait to see you tonight.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My duty to justice, to the law, to the people in this room. My promise to Mia, to be present, to make these last hours count. I stood there, torn, the courtroom silent, my mind racing between the bench and the woman I loved.
